body: Ignore update 2ff6961 as it is not backward compatible since it is impossible to use a `DatasetState` instance to deserialize a serialized `JobState` object. The `SequenceFile.Reader.next()` method will throw an `IOException` because the value classes are different.
Added some more metrics: (1) the earliest and average timestamps each writer writes. Used to measure latency; (2) the number of kafka partitions and messages that have errors. 187b89a
LGTM other than two minor comments

This is just a suggestion:
Why not make a single dataset per glob match, and then make each file under the dataset a TimeStampedDatasetVersion? For example, if the glob is /user/*, each user will be a dataset, with one DatasetVersion per file owned by that user. You can do the proxying in the VersionFinder. Advantages:
- No need to modify ConfigurableGlobDatasetFinder
- Get empty directory cleanup for free
- (Debatable) cleaner implementation
Could you create a wki for the state model? This is a very important aspect of Gobblin that should be understood particularly by people who develop new sources?
Whats the difference between an `Extract` and a `dataset.urn`?

A `dataset.urn` is simply a more general form of dataset identifiers than an `Extract`, which feels to me too closely tight to table-based datasets. I thought about using `Extract` for dataset identifiers, but decided to use something more general in the end. I also think `Extract` itself is not super clear and intuitive.
Yes, I agree too. It's too closely tied to table based datasets. In that case, should we deprecate the `Extract` class in either this PR or a future one?

As far as I know, data purger uses `Extract` for more than just getting the output path. @sahilTakiar you can give more details on that. So we cannot deprecate it as part of this PR. In the meanwhile, we probably also need to extract `dataset.urn` into a class that can hold more information about a dataset.
@ydailinkedin Addressed comments, and fixed a bug where new methods in ProxiedFileSystem cache were not actually using cache.
Please provide a bug number and/or description of the bug and fix.

`ProxiedFileSystemUtils` should be creating new proxiedFileSystem instead of calling `ProxiedFileSystemCache.getProxiedFileSystemUsingToken`, which would result in a recursive call on `ProxiedFileSystemCache.getProxiedFileSystemUsingToken`.
LGTM.  When we move the Metric design wikis to github we should describe the pattern in the "How to write a reporter" section.
LGTM but could you re-rerun the tests with the Kafka test fix before merging?

@zliu41 Instead of setting the actual high watermark in the `WorkUnit`, which is not a good place for the `actual` high watermark, you can do so in `KafkaExtractor.close()`, which is guarantee to be called even if the task fails.

@zliu41 Can you review?
Tested on Azkaban for daily and hourly compaction
Please add license headers to new files.
Whoops - meant to cast to an int first. Changed to use Random.nextInt()

Can you re-factor the javadocs and the variables names to make it more generic. Since this method is splitting the WorkUnitStates by Predicate, it doesn't seem necessary to call one `MultiMap` `successful`, and the other one `failed`.

Also, what approach did you decide on with regards to the location of the event emission for failed `WorkUnitState`s.

@sahilTakiar Please take a look
- I have updated the javadoc. 
- The approach I am going with is to submit the events from the DataPurgerPublisher. The reason for this is I want to emit only 1 event after a workunit commit is failed. 
  If we want to emit the event from the framework, we need to make the framework aware of workunits that failed commit after the publisher has attempted to commit data. Also, each publisher (for Eg. DataPurgerPublisher) will have custom data in the event which may not be relevant to the framework.
Why put it before job commit? This was intended to be invoked after job committed successfully, e.g., publish job level metrics. If a job fails to commit, the metrics shouldn't be published

I actually have a use case in Lynda data ingestion: the data publisher needs to know the value of a metric. What's the side effect if the Kafka ingestion job reports metrics in case of commit failure?

In Kafka ingestion, `postProcessTaskStates` will create counters such as number of records pulled. Will these counters be published if the job commit fails? If not then it's fine. It doesn't make sense to publish the counter if the job actually didn't commit those records.
Makes sense. OK, I will try a different approach for the Lynda use case.

@liyinan926 I don't understand your concern. I think the invariant is that the WorkUnit should contain a low WM, high WM and actual WM. We should try to maintain the invariant at all times, including when the WU gets created. I don't thing we should wait till the finalization in KafkaExtractor.close() to restore the invariant.

LGTM.

@chavdar the current API makes it clear that `WorkUnit` is supposed to contain static configuration and metadata only, and it should contain a `WatermarkInterval` that defines a low watermark and an expected high watermark. The `WorkUnitState`, however, is supposed to also contain runtime metadata, which includes the actual high watermark. Setting the actual high watermark violates this contract, and the Javadoc of the newly added method in `WorkUnit` in this PR also makes it clear that setting the actual high watermark in a `WorkUnit` is not a well-established pattern. It makes perfect sense to set the actual high watermark in the `close` method since at that point the actual high watermark should be well defined.
@chavdar I agree with Yinan. `Source` should set the low wm and the EXPECTED high wm. The ACTUAL high wm should be set by the `Extractor` depending on how many records it actually extracted.

About the use of METRIC_CONTEXT_NAME_KEY. It seems that this constant is defined in two different places: in ConfigurationKeys, and also in Instrumented. That is a mistake, we should use only one of them.
@zliu41 In that case the source/extractor better not throw NPEs if they don't find the actual watermark.

With the current code base, its a little weird to have a class extend `Instrumented` and to get it registered in `GobblinMetricsRegistry`. When one extends `Instrumented`, the super constructor invokes `getMetricContext` which creates a `MetricContext` properly. However, the `MetricContext` is not registered in `GobblinMetricsRegistry`. In order to get it registered, I tried to create a `GobblinMetrics` instance using the `GobblinMetrics.get()` method (which automatically registers the newly made `MetricContext` in `GobblinMetricsRegistry`). However the `get()` method requires a `parentContext` be specified. This is where the problem arises, the `Instrumented` constructor has already made a `metricContext` that is a child of `TaskMetrics`, and now `GobblinMetrics` requires a `parentContext` to be specified.

So instead I solely use `GobblinMetrics`.
It looks good. Have you tested that the metric contexts do get generated as expected?
@liyinan926 updated. Also added a new property `writer.dir.permissions` to be distinguished from `writer.file.permissions`.
If `publisherOutputDir` is created here, it may cause problem when the publisher moves `writerOutptuDir` to `publisherOutputDir` since `publisherOutputDir` already exists.
Let's discuss this in person tomorrow morning. There is too much back-and-forth.
